text: Does setting a start value to a decision variable provide any upside in terms of performance in the solving phase?

elements.text: Does setting a start value to a decision variable provide any upside in terms of performance in the solving phase?

text: depends on the algorithm you use and the problem

elements.text: depends on the algorithm you use and the problem

text: I am working with a “large” pool binary decision variables where most of them will eventually shrink to 0

elements.text: I am working with a “large” pool binary decision variables where most of them will eventually shrink to 0

text: is it a binary optimization problem?

elements.text: is it a binary optimization problem?

text: And I am using the Gurobi solver — would it makes sense to set a start value of 0 ?

elements.text: And I am using the Gurobi solver — would it makes sense to set a start value of 0 ?

text: if you use solvers like Gurobi or Cplex and if you could provide a good initial solution, it can have dramatic effect on running time

elements.text: if you use solvers like Gurobi or Cplex and if you could provide a good initial solution, it can have dramatic effect on running time

text: but you must make sure the solution you provide is actually feasible

elements.text: but you must make sure the solution you provide is actually feasible

text: but gurobi has very good heuristics for finding an initial solution. i wouldn't worry too much about setting things initially unless i really have to

elements.text: but gurobi has very good heuristics for finding an initial solution. i wouldn't worry too much about setting things initially unless i really have to

text: Sure, sounds good — I mean my current problem is more a Constraint Satisfaction and there’s no difference between any two solution,  hence my objective function is a constant

elements.text: Sure, sounds good — I mean my current problem is more a Constraint Satisfaction and there’s no difference between any two solution,  hence my objective function is a constant

text: Therefore I don’t know if Gurobi’s heuristics really work out in that sense

elements.text: Therefore I don’t know if Gurobi’s heuristics really work out in that sense

text: in that case, you probably won't provide a feasible solution. :smile:

elements.text: in that case, you probably won't provide a feasible solution.

text: you might want to tune the branching strategy instead.

elements.text: you might want to tune the branching strategy instead.

text: My assumption was that since MOST of the variables will stay to 0, setting 0 as a start value MIGHT help the solver — but it looks like I am wrong

text: Oh, sounds interesting! Do you have any documentation on how to do that with JuMP / Gurobi?

text: you need to use the set attribute feature in JuMP.

attachments.title: How to use Gurobi variable hints in JuMP 0.21
attachments.text: Hi, I was wondering whether it was possible to access the Gurobi variable hint attributes <https://www.gurobi.com/documentation/9.0/refman/varhintval.html#attr:VarHintVal> using JuMP, or failing that by accessing a lower level model. As a concrete working example, suppose that I’m solving a Knapsack problem using JuMP/Gurobi, namely using JuMP, Gurobi m=Model(Gurobi.Optimizer) set_optimizer_attribute(m, "ResultFile", "theHintFile.sol") @variable(m, z[1:5], Bin) @objective(m, Min, sum(z)) @const...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: How to use Gurobi variable hints in JuMP 0.21
